title: Techno solutionism and innovation
content:
Most popular approaches today that address change are based on the idea of human ingenuity being able to solve any problem. Technological progress and innovation have pushed the limits of what humanity is capable of doing. This reinforces the idea that humankind will be able to fix anything. Such solutionist approaches follow the idea of broken mechanics, implying that the planet can be fixed. Yet, as Timothy Morton points out regarding the relation of humans to their non-human environment: “It didn't ever function, ever”. (Morton, 2020) We cannot “fix” something that never was working. In the face of the need for massive-scale change, the assumption is that equally massive power is needed to enact it. As a result, we see the rise of billionaires like Elon Musk that supposedly can get us out of the mess we're in, promising to geoengineer the way out of the crisis – or to at least colonise a nearby planet if it fails. Techno-saviour figures like Musk are the white wizards of our time, freeing us from the responsibility to act for ourselves.
Thereby, huge irrational trust is put in some genius engineer or institution to innovate and find a solution (finding an antidote, stopping glaciers from melting, dry skin, etc.). But techno optimistic solutions like antidotes or geoengineering would need to get things perfectly right, as otherwise, the consequences could be dreadful.
Moreover, to solve problems techno-solutionist approaches tend to reproduce problematic dynamics, e.g. replacing cars with electric cars, instead of addressing the underlying issues of personal mobility.
